image.altText: Nathan Cleary

props.synopsis: Brisbane had Penrith dead to rights with 20 minutes left in the grand final but they gave Nathan Cleary just enough time to cement his legend.

title.children: Nathan Cleary's NRL grand final performance cements his place alongside modern greats

image.altText: An aerial photo of a small, busy town at sunset with a hotel in the foreground and cars parked along the main street.

props.synopsis: Converted airports, refurbished nursing homes, caravans, sheds and school camps aren't considered suitable housing options. But they're all in the mix as workers struggle to find a place to live near their workplace that they can afford.

title.children: This seaside town is so popular that employers are turning an aged care home into accommodation for their staff

image.altText: a house for sale in the brisbane suburb of stafford with the sale sign in the front yard

props.synopsis: Housing data for September shows prices rose 0.8 per cent, led by Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth, despite a gradual increase in properties for sale and higher interest rates.

title.children: House prices on track to hit new record high, continuing to frustrate first home buyers

image.altText: A bearded man smiles slightly in front of lake and reeds of grass at sunset

props.synopsis: Seaweed, cows and cutting-edge science: This is how Sam Elsom swapped fashion for farming to spearhead a revolutionary climate change solution. But he's facing a major obstacle.

title.children: How a humble seaweed inspired Sam to build an innovative solution to climate change

image.altText: A Brisbane Broncos NRL player scores a try in the grand final.

props.synopsis: Penrith launches a comeback for the ages to earn legendary status, Brisbane is made to pay for botched drop-outs, while Ezra Mam lights up the grand final. These are the five quick hits from Penrith's third consecutive premiership triumph.

title.children: NRL grand final five quick hits: Costly kicking errors crush Broncos despite Mam magic

image.altText: Jesse Arthars of the Brisbane Broncos sits against a goalpost after the NRL grand final.

props.synopsis: Coming so close to winning the NRL premiership and missing out has proven hard to overcome for some sides, and the most brutal but effective teacher for others. Now we will see how the Broncos handle it, writes Jon Healy.

title.children: The Broncos are young, but one key piece is on a different timeline and the clock is ticking after the grand final

image.altText: A jetty extending over the ocean with a sign in the foreground that says Beachport jetty.

props.synopsis: A woman has serious leg injuries after being attacked by a shark at Beachport in South Australia's south-east, police say.

title.children: Woman bitten by shark at regional SA beach rushed to hospital

image.altText: A man in glasses holds his hand out as he speaks into microphone.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Investigation launched after US congressman sets off fire alarm, NSW govt faces renewed calls to bring in pill-testing. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New data suggests Australian house prices are on track to hit a record high, despite the pressure of rising interest rates. CoreLogic housing data shows prices rose 0.8 per cent nationally in September. The median price of a home is now $1,110,660 in Sydney, $776,716 in Melbourne and $691,591 in Adelaide. You can read more here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: House prices on track to hit record high

featuredLink.title: House prices on track to hit new record high, continuing to frustrate first home buyers

Australian house prices
are on track to hit a record high, despite the pressure of rising interest rates.
CoreLogic housing data shows prices rose
0.8 per cent
nationally in September.
The
median price
of a home is now $1,110,660 in Sydney, $776,716 in Melbourne and $691,591 in Adelaide.
You can read more here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US gymnast Simone Biles has made history on her return to the World Championships in Antwerp, Belgium becoming the first woman to land a Yurchenko double pike vault. She scored 15.266 for the move which is rated as the most difficult jump in the women's scoring code. It helped the 26 year old into first place in all-around qualifying. Biles is competing internationally for the first time since taking a two-year break from the sport to work on her mental health.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US gymnast Simone Biles makes history at World Championships

children.content: US gymnast
Simone Biles
has made history on her return to the World Championships in
Antwerp, Belgium
becoming the first woman to land a Yurchenko double pike vault.
She scored 15.266 for the move which is rated as the most difficult jump in the women's scoring code.
It helped the 26 year old into first place in all-around qualifying.
Biles is competing internationally for the first time since taking a two-year break from the sport to work on her mental health.

props.alt: A woman stands with her hands up, wearing a light-blue leotard.

children.content: Simone Biles is the first woman to land the Yurchenko double pike vault.
(Reuters: Yves Herman)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Half of the country can officially vote early in the Voice to Parliament referendum today. Early voting begins on Monday October 2 for the following states and territories: Northern Territory Tasmania Victoria Western Australia You can read more on where to vote early and who is eligible in the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Early referendum voting starts today for half of Australia

featuredLink.title: Early referendum voting starts today in half the country. Here's where to vote early and who's eligible

children.content: Half of the country can officially vote early in the Voice to Parliament referendum today.
Early voting begins on Monday October 2 for the following states and territories:
Northern Territory
Tasmania
Victoria
Western Australia
You can read more on where to vote early and who is eligible in the link below.

image.altText: Trees and a road with the Broken Hill Line of Lode.

props.synopsis: Health workers renew calls for a rehabilitation centre in Broken Hill, after a report reveals Indigenous Australians are almost four times as likely as other Australians to die of a drug overdose.

title.children: Calls for outback rehab centre reignited by alarming data on overdose deaths

image.altText: A firefighter in front of a room on fire.

props.synopsis: The fire broke out in the early hours of Sunday in adjoining nightclubs in Atalayas, on the outskirts of the city Murcia in south-east Spain.

title.children: At least 13 dead in Spanish nightclub fire as families search for missing people

image.altText: Woman with white hair in green shirt with resigned and upset expression stands in front of highway backdrop

props.synopsis: Four years ago these residents of Sussex Inlet were trapped in their town, cut off by fire. They fear the same thing could happen this summer.

title.children: NSW communities fear Black Summer 'deja vu' as fuel loads increase along key road routes

image.altText: A student at Yipirinya School wiping his eye.

props.synopsis: For decades, an eye disease known as trachoma was stealing the sight of Indigenous Australians. Now, the disease is on its way to being eradicated.

title.children: How this little-known eye infection is still stealing sight in parts of Australia

image.altText: A woman with a pink shawl over her shoulders holds a newborn baby in her arms

props.synopsis: With no local maternity services, women in Bourke cannot have their babies on country, but they are being welcomed back to their ancestral land.

title.children: Baby Amahlee wasn't born on country, but an ancient Indigenous tradition has welcomed her home

image.altText: People standing in individual booths at a polling centre.

props.synopsis: Early voting for the Voice to Parliament referendum kicks off this week for those who are unable to vote on October 14.

title.children: Early referendum voting starts today in half the country. Here's where to vote early and who's eligible

image.altText: Couple discussing finances in front of computer surrounded by colour treatment as the woman holds a mug

props.synopsis: Struggling with bills and debt? Be careful where you go for help. Some services, such as financial counselling, are free and independent, but some so-called "debt relief" firms can be predatory and harmful.

title.children: 'You shouldn't pay to get out of financial hardship': What to know before seeking help with debt

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australian stocks are poised to start the final quarter of this year lower, while the Reserve Bank is almost universally tipped to hold interest rates steady in tomorrow's board meeting. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to drop ahead of RBA interest rate decision, Wall Street mixed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: House prices are on track to hit a new record high, despite a gradual increase in properties for sale and the pressure of higher interest rates. CoreLogic housing data showed prices rose 0.8 per cent nationally in September, led by Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth, where housing supply remains about 40 per cent below the five-year average. The median price of a home is now $1,110,660 in Sydney, $776,716 in Melbourne and $691,591 in Adelaide. Read more from Isobel Roe .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: House prices continute to rise

featuredLink.title: House prices on track to hit new record high, continuing to frustrate first homebuyers

children.content: House prices are on track to hit a new record high, despite a gradual increase in properties for sale and the pressure of higher interest rates.
CoreLogic housing data showed prices rose 0.8
per cent nationally in September, led by Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth, where housing supply remains about 40 per cent below the five-year average.
The median price of a home is now $1,110,660 in Sydney, $776,716 in Melbourne and $691,591 in Adelaide.
Read more from
Isobel Roe

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Data showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August, the first time in over two years it had fallen below 4 per cent. The Fed tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target. The data revealed a "better than expected but still elevated inflation picture", said Eric Freedman, chief investment officer at US Bank Asset Management. The highly anticipated PCE data followed the recent hawkish long-term outlook for rates from the US Federal Reserve, which has rattled stocks as benchmark Treasury yields climbed to 16-year highs. "Equity investors are finally waking up to the Fed and the Fed comments that it is going to be higher for longer, and there is an alternative to stocks," said Paul Nolte, senior wealth advisor and market strategist for Murphy & Sylvest Wealth Management.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation subsides

children.content: Data showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August, the first time in over two years it had fallen below 4 per cent.
The Fed tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target.
The data revealed a "better than expected but still elevated inflation picture", said Eric Freedman, chief investment officer at US Bank Asset Management.
The highly anticipated PCE data followed the recent hawkish long-term outlook for rates from the US Federal Reserve, which has rattled stocks as benchmark Treasury yields climbed to 16-year highs.

"Equity investors are finally waking up to the Fed and the Fed comments that it is going to be higher for longer, and there is an alternative to stocks," said Paul Nolte, senior wealth advisor and market strategist for Murphy
Sylvest Wealth Management.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to Monday's markets live blog, where we'll bring you the latest price action and news on the ASX and beyond. And it looks like it could be a negative start, with ASX futures lower. It follows a mixed session on Wall Street last Friday. The S & P 500 and Nasdaq posted their biggest monthly percentage drops of the year, while all three major indexes had their first quarterly declines in 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to slide

children.content: Good morning and welcome to Monday's markets live blog, where we'll bring you the latest price action and news on the ASX and beyond.
And it looks like it could be a negative start, with
ASX futures lower.
It follows a mixed session on Wall Street last Friday.
The S
P 500 and Nasdaq posted their biggest monthly percentage drops of the year, while all three major indexes had their first quarterly declines in 2023.

image.altText: A view of the Dargo Hotel, with bushfire smoke-filled air.

props.synopsis: Crews are working to contain multiple fires in Victoria's east as forecast winds approach, with confirmation at least one house and about 5,000 hectares have burnt in the spring blazes.

title.children: Hundreds of campers stranded in Victoria's east as 'shock' spring bushfires claim one home

image.altText: A sign on the roadside displaying coloured triangles with different fire risk ratings, with dense, green bushland behind it.

props.synopsis: For some people, the coming warmer months are not a celebration. They are something to fear, or feel sad about, writes Tara Crandon.

title.children: Not everyone is excited about the warmer months. For some, summer can trigger anxiety and grief

image.altText: Rory McIlroy throws his hat and grimaces

props.synopsis: Rory McIlroy said he was "the angriest I have ever been in my career" after his altercation on day two of the Ryder Cup. But he was able to refocus and led Europe to a dominant victory in Rome.

title.children: 'Angriest' Rory McIlroy leads Europe to dominant Ryder Cup victory over USA

image.altText: Fraser McReight dives over

props.synopsis: The Wallabies conceded the first try and had two players sent to the sin bin, but still managed to keep their faint Rugby World Cup hopes alive with a victory over Portugal — now they need Os Lobos to do them a huge favour.

title.children: Five quick hits — a shock Portugal lead and the Wallabies hold firm with 13 men to stay alive at the World Cup

image.altText: General wearing military uniform and series of medals.

props.synopsis: Junta officials say a national census, which critics warn will be used to increase surveillance of opponents, has to be completed ahead of elections that were delayed in August.

title.children: Myanmar junta wants census, biometric identification systems ahead of delayed election

image.altText: Angus Bell is hugged

props.synopsis: The Wallabies are still an outside chance of qualifying for the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals, recording a bonus point win against a brave Portuguese side despite being reduced to 13 men during the second half.

title.children: Wallabies beat Portugal to stay alive at the Rugby World Cup

image.altText: An official is taken away on a stretcher

props.synopsis: A horrific hammer mishap has resulted in an official at the Asian Games being hospitalised after an errant throw saw the projectile smash into and break the 62-year-old's leg.

title.children: Horror hammer mishap sees official hospitalised at Asian Games

image.altText: A middle-aged man with short brown hair leaning against an AFL post, while holding a yellow football.

props.synopsis: Leigh McDonald's depression and anxiety have "gone through the roof" over the past five years — a result, he believes, of the large number of concussions he suffered while playing amateur Aussie Rules football.

title.children: Footy gave Leigh his identity, but the head knocks have started to strip away his personality

image.altText: Rebecca Jeffcoat wearing goggles and sub-zero protective clothing in Antarctic landscape.

props.synopsis: It's one of the most challenging work environments on the planet. But with hundreds of applicants, the process of selecting the best candidate takes eight months and resembles a reality TV contest.

title.children: Reckon you can handle a year in Antarctica as a station leader? This is what it takes to pass the test

image.altText: A video screen grab of an explosion on the side of a street.

props.synopsis: The Turkish defence ministry says its warplanes have carried out raids on suspected Kurdish rebel targets in northern Iraq following a suicide attack on a government building in the Turkish capital.

title.children: Türkiye strikes suspected Kurdish militant targets in northern Iraq after suicide attack in Ankara

image.altText: Elise Archer rests her head on her hand in parliament.

props.synopsis: Former Tasmanian Liberal MP Elise Archer says she's "reconsidering" quitting state parliament and might sit as an Independent, which an electoral analyst says could trigger an early state election.

title.children: Elise Archer 'reconsidering' quitting parliament, early election risk for Tasmanian Liberals

props.synopsis: Local residents say they heard the sound of a whale crying out early Sunday morning before a calf was released from a shark net.

title.children: Sound of trapped humpback whale calf heard across Sunshine Coast suburb before rescue

image.altText: Large crowd at music festival

props.synopsis: Two men in their 20s have died after attending the Knockout Outdoor festival, while nine urgent medical transfers were made from Listen Out festival at Centennial Park.

title.children: 'It's horrible': Two people dead after attending Knockout Outdoor music festival in Sydney

image.altText: Colourful pencils on a desk in a childcare centre.

props.synopsis: Australian parents facing crippling cost-of-living pressures are paying almost twice the OECD average for child care, an ACCC inquiry finds, with the system also failing to deliver for low-income families and those in the bush.

title.children: Australia's for-profit childcare system favours the wealthy and needs a major re-design: ACCC

image.altText: Woman wearing pink pyjamas in a hospital bed with a drip in her arm.

props.synopsis: It's estimated one in five Australians live with chronic pain and lobby group Painaustralia is calling for more Medicare-funded allied health visits for those living with the condition.

title.children: 'We don't look sick': Megan wants others to know what it's like living with chronic pain

image.altText: Two people sharing a cup of tea at a table.

props.synopsis: The central Victorian community of Heathcote has become a hub of dementia innovation, driven by passionate volunteers and the local hospital.

title.children: A small community helping people with dementia has created a house that's 'almost like another carer'

image.altText: Ken, on the left, and Louis, on the right, wearing white clothes covered in bright colours after doing a colour run

props.synopsis: When Ken turned 94 in July, there was one birthday card that stood out to him — it was written by a teenager he met in a social experiment who he now counts as a close friend.

title.children: Despite a 78-year age gap, Ken and Louis connected over their shared grief. Now they're firm friends

image.altText: A young white woman in a wheelchair out on the street

props.synopsis: The role of special schools is again in the spotlight, with the disability royal commission recommending segregated education be phased out.

title.children: Australia has long been divided on 'special schools'. Now the disability royal commission is too

props.synopsis: Irish band U2 christen the stage of the new $3.4 billion spherical stage structure dubbed the "future of music" in Las Vegas, Nevada.

title.children: Las Vegas Sphere hosts first concert, putting on spectacle for U2 fans
